div1.p: Havard details the outbreak of yellow fever in Quemados, Cuba in May 1900. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Report from Valery Havard to the Adjutant General, June 18, 1900
div1.opener:
Havard's report on YF epidemic in Quemados
up to June 18, 1900 MAP
See Starks 2 reports
Copy
L.S.233.
HEADQUARTERS
DIVISION OF CUBA
OFFICE OF L.S.233.
HAVANA.
June 18th. 1900.
To the Adjutant General,
Division of Cuba,
Sir:-
div1.p:
I have the honor to state that, in accordance
from whom ? with instructions received on the 15th. inst., I went on the same
day to Quemados to examine into all the facts and circumstances
connected with the outbreak of yellow fever at that place, and
to submit the following report:

So far as known to the Medical Department, there were no
cases of yellow fever at Quemados in 1899, and after the many
sanitary improvements made in that town it was confidently ex-
pected that none would occur this year. There were many cases
of an infectious fever among the troops at Columbia Barracks,
last fall, but they have been identified as Dengue fever. see Saleeby file

From the mode of origination of the cases in the present
outbreak, and the absence of any history of recent introduction
of infection, it is fair to assume that the yellow fever at
Quemados is attributable to the presence of old germs existing
in the occupied buildings. Why such germs should suddenly be-
come active after such a long period of quiescence, is still an
unanswerable question, and one about which it would now be profit
less to speculate.

The first case (Mrs. King) began on May 16th., but it was
mind, no physician was called in and it passed unrecognized.
L.S.233. (2)
Her husband (King, Quartermaster's employe) was taken sick on
the 19th., seen by a Cuban physician on the 21st. and by Major
Kean on the 22nd., first date on which the existence of yellow
fever was recognized. It was then that the illness of Mrs. King
was inquired into and found to be yellow fever.

Three more cases (Signal Serg't. Sherwood, child and wife)
occurred in the same house (20, General Lee Street), on the 23rd.
30th. and June 3rd. respectively.

On May 30th. Private Valentine, Co. “D” 8th. Cavalry, was taken
sick in his quarters (Columbia Barracks) and admitted to hosp-
ital on the 31st.

The next three cases (Private Teeter, Hospital Corps, Qmr's.
Serg't. Reilly and Shenk, Qmr's. employe) occurred in a house near-
ly adjoining the first, (102, Real Calzada), on June 3rd., 6th. and
8th. respectively. All subsequent cases occurred on General Lee
Street, with the exception of one Qmr's. employe who apparently
contracted the disease at the Headquarters Corral. It is thus
seen, as the accompanying sketch indicates, that the foci of con-
tagion are limited to a well defined district.

The total number of cases, to date, is 19, namely 13 civil-
ians (all Americans), l U.S.A. officer and 5 enlisted men. The
officer (Major Edmunds), a man of excellent habits, lives in one
of the cleanest and best ventilated houses in town, and in which
Major Kean and family lived last summer with impunity. He very likely caug-
ht the disease from the house; this opinion is strengthened by
the fact that he and his wife contracted it almost simultaneous-
ly, and that so far as known, they did not visit any infected
place or person.

The mode of infection of the 5 enlisted men, so far as as-
certainable, is as follows:-

1. Serg't. Sherwood, Signal Serg't., from his residence (General
Lee Street)
2. Private Teeter, Hospital Corps, from his residence (Real Calzada St.)
3. Serg't. Reilly, Qmr's. Serg't. from his residence (Real St.)

4. Private Valentine, Co. “D”, 8th. Inft'y., unknown: he claims to
have slept every night in his quarters. Close watch of every
other man of his Co. has failed to discover another case.

5. Corp. Walker, Troop “H”, 7th. Cavalry, from house in town (Gener-
al Lee Street) where he kept a mistress.

The mortality thus far has only been 3, namely Signal Serg't
Sherwood and 2 civilians, thus indicating a rather mild type of
infection.

There is no sign or indication that any part of Columbia
Barracks is or has been infected.

The post isolation hospital is situated across the rail-
road track at a safe distance from the Barracks and is well
equipped and furnished.

I find that all necessary measures of isolation and dis-
infection have been thoughtfully planned and diligently carried
out by the Chief Surgeon, Major Kean.

A strict quarantine is maintained by Columbia Barracks
against Quemados. Of course it is of the utmost importance that
as little intercourse as possible should exist between the two
places and that no officer or enlisted man be allowed to enter
Quemados except on strictly official business and by special
orders.

A measure immediately required is the establishment of a
detention camp where all non-immunes are to be at once removed
when exposed, or when suspected to have been exposed, to infect-
ion. I am informed by Chief Surgeon Kean that steps are being
taken to that end and I recommend that there be no delay about
it.

The question of vacating the barracks and removing the
troops to a camp, naturally suggests itself. I do not believe
that such a serious and radical measure is necessary at present, and
trust it will never be; but as it might become necessary, it is
advisable that a suitable camp be selected now and that all the
required canvas be made available.

All necessary arrangements have been made to vacate any
individual set of quarters showing signs of infection, that is
in which a case of yellow fever originates.

In conclusion, I wish to say that the medical personnel,
under the direction of Major Kean, is unusually able and effic-
ient and that every medical officer may be relied upon to do
his duty.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully yours, (Signed) V Havard Major and Surgeon, U.S.A.
Chief Surgeon.
